Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Jamie, and my heart sank as I read her reply. She thought I was annoyed with her, but it was just a rushed text—nothing more. I knew I should call her right away, clear things up before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do: talk things out, make sure nothing festers. But as I glanced at the clock, panic crept in. The polling station would close in less than two hours, and I still had to get there. Voting mattered to me; it was my responsibility, my voice. I couldn’t let the day slip by without casting my ballot. Yet, Jamie’s hurt echoed in my mind, and I imagined her waiting for my call, needing reassurance. I felt pulled in two directions—one by loyalty to my friend, the other by my duty as a citizen. My hands trembled as I held my phone, torn between dialing her number and grabbing my keys to rush out the door.
